The behavior of the great bull elephants: They pull up lotus bulbs with their trunks
They wash them thoroughly until they are free of mud
It is good for their appearance and health, and wouldn’t result in death or deadly pain
The behavior of the young cubs (a causal: They pull up lotus bulbs with their trunks
They chew and swallow them while they are still muddy
It is not good for their appearance and health, and results in death or deadly pain
The behavior of senior mendicants (a cau: They robe up in the morning
They take their bowl and robe
They enter the town or village for alms
Lay people demonstrate their confidence in them
When they get things, they use them untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape
It is good for their appearance and health, and doesn’t result in death or deadly pain
The behavior of junior mendicants (a cau: They robe up in the morning
They take their bowl and robe
They enter the town or village for alms
Lay people demonstrate their confidence in them
When they get things, they use them tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, not understanding the escape
It is not good for their appearance and health, and results in death or deadly pain
The training that should be followed (a: When we get things, we will use them untied
